title: Ticket #1208: Dataflow with Files using Dagman
description:
This ticket sketches a description of a possible enhancement to the DAGMan functionality.

The enhancement is that if you have two nodes in this relationship A->B, when node A produces, and completes, a file Af that B solely requires to run, then B may immediately start, even though A is still running possibly producing other files for other nodes. This mimics much more of a dataflow dependency instead of a job completion dependency. Additionally, when Af is noticed and moved to where ever it needs to go so B can run, an event is written into the event log associated with the node such that we don't try to move the file again in other circumstances.

Milestones

The branch holding this work is V7_5-dataflow-2-branch.

  • [condor_starter change]: Periodically bring closed output files back to spool [DONE]
    1. Implement a means to get the open files of a running process. [DONE]
    2. Implement: user turns on dataflow semantics with jobad attr, timer in starter to perform checks. transfer-dataflow-output-files [DONE enough]
    3. Modify the FileTransfer object to:
      1. Get all pids for job's process tree and get list of open files. #1515 [DONE]
      2. Using the filetransfer api, get the list: 
        (filter (closed-file-in-pids-p job-pids)
 (filter output-file-p
  (enumerate-sandbox-files job-pids)))
      3. Transfer that list back as if ON_EVICT_OR_EXIT. [DONE]

  • [file-transfer object change]: Make it so closed dataflow files are only brought back ONCE. Currently, even though the dataflow file is closed, it is brought back multiple times. If the file is repoened and closed again, maybe it can be brought back again (which would actually violate our assumptions so it needs to be seriously considered), but also only ONCE until the next time. This should be implemented by augmenting the file atalog to allow dynamic insertion of files into it after it has been created. I also need to check at final upload time that if there are dataflow files in the file catalog to NOT transfer them.

Assumptions

  • The files that are to be created by an executing node and used in the dataflow must have these semantics. This is more restrictive than how the filetransfer object decides a file is considered an output file or an intermediate file.
    1. The created file must not exist in the sandbox manifest.
    2. The file is atomically created and opened for use, once.
    3. Once the file is closed, it stays closed.
  • There is a way on Linux/Unix to determine the open files a process is using.
  • Condor knows a manifest of the sandbox, to determine when these files are present.
  • There is a means by which the files can be moved asynchronously out of the job execution directory while the job is still running.

Feasibility

  • Determination of open files by a process on Linux.
    • If one looks in the directory /proc/<pid>/fd you will find a list of fds opened by the process and the files to which they point. Using the command stat we can see that the read/write status of the fd is available for that file. This information is thusly available.
    • If one knows the manifest of the sandbox, then any file added to the sandbox that is not referenced by an open fd would be considered a candidate for execution interleaving of a future node.
    • Feasible to find files in the correct state on Linux: YES
  • Condor today knows the sandbox manifest.
  • Condor would need functionality to implement asynchronous file transfer while job is still running.

Problems

  • Idempotency of output files under retry/eviction/crash conditions. In this scenario:
    1. job A starts up
    2. file Af is produced.
    3. file Af is asynchronously transfered back and committed.
    4. execute node crashes/evicts/etc/fails.
    5. Job A restarts (also could with RETRY) on potentially different node.

    What will happen is file Af will appear as an input file in the sandbox when the job restarts. If the job is unware of the previous state it had written, it will regenerate Af, as which point the FileTransfer object will see it as an output file, and transfer it back again--overwriting the first transfer, causing a duplicate dataflow message, and making the entire dataflow possibly inconsistent unless care is taken. If the job is aware of the previous state and does not regenerate Af, then Af will never be transferred back and all is well.

  • Dataflow connections between nodes do not have infinite capacity to store tokens. Example: if in the dataflow A->B, B consumes data tokens at a slower rate than A produces them, we would run out of disk space. So, when we're getting close to our allotment of space denoted for that specific stream, how do we signal A to stop? Suspend the process? other?

  • If a job creates large temporary files, closes them, and reads them as for a table lookup or something similar, then they could be incorrectly flagged as a dataflow file (if the program opens and closes it now and then, but only reads it) and moved back, potentially causing space issues on the submit node or network bandwidth issues. NOTE: This can be fixed by allowing the user to specify via regex a list of files that should be considered to have dataflow semantics.

Real world Jobs

  • Some real world jobs don't fall under workflow model.
    • Jobs which do things like:
      1. compute result
      2. open file with append
      3. write result
      4. close file
      5. repeat
    • Jobs which overwrite their previous output files on restart.

  • Real world examples of jobs that could benefit
    • Craig Struble had a workflow where an image generation phase of N processes generated N images (where N is 200,000 or so) and then an accumulation phase summed the image into a single image. His main problem was that if you rendered workflow this as a DAG, you'd need storage space for 200,000 images--which were individually large and he didn't have that much space. Since DAGMan can't run a job until all of their parents complete, we are forced to store all 200,000 images before the accumulator process is run.

      The solution we came up with was there is a DAG producing the N images and the space needed for returning images is controlled by DAG throttling. Then, the post scripts on the image nodes copy the resultant image into a directory using unix rename()--which is atomic, where a seperate scheduler universe process is polling every X seconds and accumulating the partial results into the final image. When the DAG finishes, the final node writes a 'done' messge into the directory which completes the dataflow.

      This real world job is the exact type of dataflow job that the feature of this ticket could solve.

References

  • Flow Based Programming
    • Flow Based Programming - Book
  • Advances in Dataflow Programming Languages - This is particularly good.
  • A data-driven workflow language for grids based on array programming principles - Interesting.
remarks:
2010-Feb-17 11:16:30 by psilord:
This ticket has no dated milestones yet since I am in discussion with Miron about the scope of the initial milestone. However, since I'm doing some research in the code and general thinking about it, it is marked as active.

2010-Mar-17 14:03:34 by psilord:
Implementing.

2010-Mar-23 12:00:59 by psilord:
I've written the function which will retrieve the set of files currently held open by the process. This works on Linux only.

2010-Apr-07 15:28:35 by psilord:
missed deadline due to 7.5.2 wrangling. Moving forward another two weeks due to condor week.

2010-May-06 16:47:13 by psilord:
About to start on this project. Have to finish #1195 first. Then I'll set a milestone date.

2010-Sep-28 14:47:22 by psilord:
Created a new branch V7_5-dataflow-2-branch from the master and merged V7_5-dataflow-branch to it. I'm abandoning the V7_5-dataflow-branch.

I did this because danb made the filetransfer code directory aware on the master and I thought it'd be a good idea to have that knowledge present when changing the filetransfer object to periodically move the dataflow files back since now they can reside in directories.

2010-Sep-30 16:31:05 by psilord:
Ok the merge was done. Hacking code again.

After more testing, in the dataflow timer handler, once I get the set of opened files I know I shouldn't transfer, pass that information to UploadFiles which won't pass those files on. If I leave the other UploadFiles code alone, then it should correctly see to transfer the files again if they've been updated.

2010-Oct-20 10:41:25 by psilord:
I had been making good progress. I've changed UploadFiles to accept two more arguments: a "doing dataflow" flag, and an STL set which contains the set of open files from the job family under the starter. It is intended that when doing dataflow, only the dataflow files which have been closed and not already sent, will be sent.

I'm in the middle of having ComputeFilesToSend() pick out the right files in the dataflow to send back to the spool.

However, I just got preempted by ticket #1722 and #1723.

2010-Oct-20 16:03:30 by jfrey:
Bulk change of target version from v070504 to v070505 using ./ticket-target-mover.
2011-Jan-27 14:46:04 by danb:
Bulk change of target version from v070505 to v070506 using ./ticket-target-mover.

2011-Jan-28 16:43:29 by psilord:
Ok, I finally got it working so that only closed files which are specifically dataflow files are brought back to the spool directory.

Now I have to make it so that this happens only ONCE for a closed dataflow file.

I think I will add the feature of: If a closed dataflow file which has already been transferred is open/closed again, it will be transferred again once.

This allows people who write checkpoint files to write to the same file and use dataflow to store the checkpoint file into the spool at periodic times.

However, it does go against the assumptions initially laid out. But...there is a user who'd use (some guy in ChemE maybe? gthain knows) it if it had that feature. :)

2011-Jan-28 16:44:21 by psilord:
I still need to clean up what I have a little bit and commit it to the branch... I'll do that monday.
2011-Feb-01 16:01:00 by tannenba:
Bulk change of target version from v070506 to NULL using ./ticket-target-mover.

2011-Feb-07 16:08:12 by psilord:
Fixed behavior so that the dataflow files are transferred ONCE after being closed. I did this by inserting the transferred dataflow files into the FileCatalog.

2011-Mar-11 11:48:38 by psilord:
I made a new branch from master called V7_7-dataflow-branch to which I am merging V7_5-dataflow-2-branch. I'm in the middle of merging and testing what I merged. When I'm done, the dataflow stuff will exist on the V7_7-dataflow-branch.

2011-Mar-30 11:35:34 by psilord:
The next thing I need to do with this is merge it into the master.

2011-Apr-01 15:39:23 by psilord:
Stalled due to preemption.

2011-Oct-28 10:33:01 by psilord:
I'm getting rid of languishing stalled tickets and putting this back to new.
